title: 103_s1938
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Amendments of 1994" and references amendments to the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Act of 1981. The purpose of the Act is stated in Section 2. The purpose of the "Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Amendments of 1994" is to assist low-income households with their home energy needs by providing grants to States for programs and activities. Authorization of appropriations is also included in the Act. The "Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Amendments of 1994" authorizes necessary sums for fiscal years 1995-1999. $50,000,000 for 1995-1996, $60,000,000 for 1997, $70,000,000 for 1998, and $80,000,000 for 1999 are authorized for section 2607A. The "Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Amendments of 1994" authorizes necessary sums for fiscal years 1995-1999, with $50,000,000 for 1995-1996, $60,000,000 for 1997, $70,000,000 for 1998, and $80,000,000 for 1999 allocated to section 2607A. Amounts appropriated for each fiscal year are specified accordingly. The subsection (c) funds for a fiscal year are available for implementing this title in the next fiscal year. SEC. 4. EMERGENCY FUNDS. Authorization of Appropriations for additional home energy assistance needs of States in case of natural disasters or emergencies. Funds are designated as emergency requirements and can only be accessed after a formal budget request by the President to Congress. The President can request emergency funds for home energy assistance in case of natural disasters or emergencies. The Secretary has the authority to allot these funds to one or more states based on the extent of the emergency's impact and other relevant factors. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZED USES OF FUNDS. Section 2605(b)(1) is amended to allow the use of funds for outreach to low-income households, intervention in energy crisis situations, promoting home energy self-sufficiency, residential weatherization, energy conservation education, and state energy planning. The State is responsible for planning, developing, and administering the program under this title, and must not use the funds for any other purposes. SEC. 6. TARGETING OF ASSISTANCE TO HOUSEHOLDS WITH HIGH HOME ENERGY BURDENS. Amendments are made to household income eligibility criteria, outreach activities, and assistance levels to prioritize households with high home energy costs or needs. Amendments are made to prioritize assistance for households with high home energy burdens by targeting additional steps in the State Plan. SEC. 7. Removal of constraint on secretarial program guidance by amending Section 2605(b) (42 U.S.C. 8624(b)).

SEC. 8. Clarification of audit requirement by amending Section 2605 (42 U.S.C. 8624) to ensure compliance with the Single Audit Act.

SEC. 9. Use of Department of Energy weatherization rules to achieve program consistency. Section 2605(c)(1)(D) (42 U.S.C. 8624(c)(1)(D)) is amended to include steps the State will take to address weatherization and energy-related home repair needs of households with high energy costs in relation to income. It also describes rules from the Department of Energy for the administration of its Low Income Weatherization Assistance Program that the State will follow for the use of funds provided under this title. SEC. 10. MATTERS TO BE DESCRIBED IN ANNUAL APPLICATION. Amends Section 2605(c)(1) to include reporting on the number and income levels of households assisted with funds, specifying members' age, disability status, and presence of young children. SEC. 11. REPORT OF FUNDS AVAILABLE FOR OBLIGATION. Each State must notify the Secretary of unobligated allotment two months before the fiscal year ends to receive payment for the next year. SEC. 12. MISCELLANEOUS AND TECHNICAL AMENDMENTS. In General, Section 2605(b)(7) is amended to ensure that households receiving assistance are not treated less favorably by home energy suppliers. Additionally, Section 2607A(e) is amended to change the deadline for the Incentive Program report. The technical amendments include changes to various sections of the law, such as inserting new language and making corrections to existing text. Section 2605(b) is amended to appear after paragraph (15). Section 2605(b)(3) is changed from "handicapped" to "disabled". Section 2607A(c)(2) is modified from ".0008 percent" to "0.08 percent". Section 2610(a) is amended to include "disabled" instead of "handicapped" and to add "or include young children" at the end. The amendments and repeals made by this Act will take effect on October 1, 1994.
